definition:
An integer $n$ is a [*perfect totient number*]{} if
$$n = \sum_{i = 1}^{c + 1} \phi^i(n)$$, where $\phi^i(x)$ is the
iterated totient function and $c$ is the integer such that
$\phi^c(n) = 2$.

A082897 in Sloane’s OEIS lists the first few perfect totient numbers: 3,
9, 15, 27, 39, 81, 111, 183, 243, 255, 327, 363, 471, 729, 2187, 2199,
3063, 4359, 4375, etc. It can be observed that many of these are
multiples of 3 (in fact, 4375 is the smallest one that is not divisible
by 3) and in fact all $3^x$ for $x > 0$ are perfect totient numbers.

Furthermore, $3p$ for a prime $p > 3$ is a perfect totient number if and
only if $p = 4n + 1$, where $n$ itself is also a perfect totient number.
Mohan and Suryanarayana showed why $3p$ can’t be a perfect totient
number when $p \equiv 3 \mod 4$. In regards to $3^2p$, Ianucci et al
showed that if it is a perfect totient number then $p$ is a prime of one
of three specific forms listen in their paper. It is not known if there
are any perfect totient numbers of the form $3^xp$ for $x > 3$.
